DOC.HEAD: Court Says City Did Not Discriminate Against Battered Women
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court rejected the claim by three battered women that the city of Butler discriminated against them by limiting the number of people who could live at a shelter proposed in a residential neighborhood. But the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals sent the case back to District Court to consider whether the city would be equally fair if it banned such shelters from other types of neighborhoods. Three battered women, using fictitious names, filed a class action suit challenging the City Council's refusal to approve an application by the Volunteers Against Child Abuse Center of Butler County to use a building it had contracted to buy. The suit was thrown out and the women took the case to the appeals court. In an opinion last week, the appeals court held that the ordinance limiting ``transitional'' dwellings to six residents, not counting staff members, was not arbitrary and thus did not violate the plaintiffs' constitutional rights of free association and due process. The ordinance was ``rationally related to the legitimate government objective of controlling density in a residential neighborhood,'' the court said. But in areas other than single-family-home neighborhoods, such a ban might not prove to be as rational, the court said in returning the dispute to the lower court. The plaintiffs had argued a shelter that did not house 12 to 15 women and children was economically unfeasible.
